gear.title: Gear Ratio Calculator
gear.description: Calculate gear ratio, speed ratio, and torque for simple and compound gear sets.
gear.gear_type_tooltip: Choose between a simple or compound gear set
gear.number_of_stages_tooltip: Number of gear stages in the compound set
gear.input_speed_tooltip: Rotational speed of the driving gear in Revolutions Per Minute
gear.input_torque_tooltip: Torque applied to the driving gear in Newton-meters

howItWorks.title: How the Gear Ratio Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Gear Ratio = Driven Teeth / Driving Teeth
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator computes gear ratio, speed transmission, and torque multiplication between gear sets. The gear ratio is the ratio of driven gear teeth to driving gear teeth.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select gear set type (simple or compound)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the number of teeth for driving and driven gears

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter input speed and torque

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review results including output speed and torque

seoTips: Ratio > 1 means speed reduction and torque increase
Ratio < 1 means speed increase and torque reduction
Compound gears multiply ratios for greater reduction
commonMistakes: Confusing driving and driven gears
Ignoring efficiency losses in calculations
Not accounting for gear wear over time
Using gears with incompatible pitch diameters

faqs.question: What is the difference between simple and compound gears?
faqs.answer: Simple gears consist of only two gears, while compound gear sets have multiple stages whose ratios multiply together for greater speed reduction or increase.

faqs.question: How do I increase torque using gears?
faqs.answer: Use a driven gear with more teeth than the driving gear. Every increase in ratio multiplies torque by the same factor while reducing speed proportionally.

faqs.question: What is typical gear efficiency?
faqs.answer: Well-lubricated helical gears achieve 95-98% efficiency. Worm gears may drop to 50-90% depending on the helix angle.

electrical-resistance.title: Electrical Resistance Calculator
electrical-resistance.description: Calculate electrical resistance using Ohm's law. Free resistance calculator for voltage, current, and resistance calculations.

errors.current_zero: Current cannot be zero when calculating resistance
errors.resistance_zero: Resistance cannot be zero when calculating current

electrical-resistance.info_description: This calculator uses Ohm's Law to calculate the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in electrical circuits.
electrical-resistance.formula_i: Current equals Voltage divided by Resistance
electrical-resistance.formula_r: Resistance equals Voltage divided by Current
electrical-resistance.ohms_law_explanation: V = I x R describes the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) in an electrical circuit.

howItWorks.title: How the Electrical Resistance Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: R = V / I, V = I × R, I = V / R
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator uses Ohm's Law to calculate the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance. Ohm's Law is the foundation for understanding electrical circuits.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select what you want to calculate (resistance, voltage, or current)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the two known values

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: The calculator automatically computes the unknown value

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review results including power consumption

seoTips: Voltage in Volts (V), Current in Amps (A), Resistance in Ohms
Ohm's Law applies to linear circuits only
commonMistakes: Mixing units (milliamps instead of amps)
Applying Ohm's Law to non-linear components
Ignoring temperature effects on resistance
Forgetting to calculate power dissipation

faqs.question: What is the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance?
faqs.answer: Voltage equals current times resistance (V = I × R). Increasing resistance reduces current at constant voltage, and vice versa.

faqs.question: When can I not apply Ohm's Law?
faqs.answer: Ohm's Law doesn't apply to non-linear components like diodes and transistors, because their resistance changes with voltage and current.

faqs.question: How do I calculate power consumption?
faqs.answer: Power (P) = Voltage × Current = V × I, or P = I² × R, or P = V² / R. All formulas give the same result.

material-conversion.title: Material Conversion Calculator
material-conversion.description: Convert units and quantities for engineering materials including weight, length, area, and volume conversions.

errors.invalid_input: Please enter a valid numeric value

material-conversion.info_description: This calculator converts between different units of measurement commonly used in engineering and construction.
material-conversion.use_case_1: Converting between metric and imperial units
material-conversion.conversion_explanation: Values are converted through their base units to ensure accuracy across all measurement systems.

howItWorks.title: How the Material Conversion Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Converted Value = Original Value × Conversion Factor
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator converts between different units of measurement for weight, length, area, and volume, accounting for material densities when needed.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select conversion type (weight, length, area, or volume)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the value to convert

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Choose source and target units

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review the conversion result

useCases: Converting between metric and imperial systems
commonMistakes: Confusing weight and mass
Ignoring material density when converting volume to weight
Using approximate conversion factors in precision applications
Confusing US and UK gallons

faqs.question: What is the difference between metric and US tons?
faqs.answer: Metric ton = 1000 kg, US (short) ton = 907.185 kg, UK (long) ton = 1016.05 kg.

faqs.question: How do I convert volume to weight?
faqs.answer: Weight = Volume × Density. Example: 1 cubic meter of steel (density 7850 kg/m3) = 7850 kg.

faqs.question: What units are most common in construction?
faqs.answer: In most countries: metric system (meters, kilograms, liters). In the US: feet, pounds, gallons. Converting between them is essential for international projects.

stress_strain.title: Stress and Strain Calculator
stress_strain.description: Calculate mechanical stress, strain, and Young's modulus for materials under load.
stress_strain.force_tooltip: Force applied to the material in Newtons (N)
stress_strain.area_tooltip: Area perpendicular to the force in square millimeters
stress_strain.original_length_tooltip: Initial length of the material before deformation
stress_strain.strain_tooltip: Dimensionless ratio of deformation to original length
stress_strain.material_tooltip: Select material for Young's modulus reference

errors.strain_zero: Strain cannot be zero when calculating Young's modulus

stress_strain.info_description: This calculator determines the mechanical stress, strain, and material properties based on applied forces and dimensions.
stress_strain.formula_strain: Strain = Change in Length / Original Length
stress_strain.hookes_law_explanation: Within the elastic limit, stress is directly proportional to strain. This relationship is defined by Young's modulus (E).

howItWorks.title: How the Stress and Strain Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Stress (sigma) = F/A, Strain (epsilon) = delta L/L0, E = sigma/epsilon
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator computes stress (force per area), strain (deformation ratio), and Young's modulus which relates them. These concepts are fundamental to materials mechanics.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select what to calculate (stress, strain, or Young's modulus)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter applied force and cross-sectional area

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter original length and change in length

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review results and material properties

seoTips: Stress is measured in Pascals (Pa) or Megapascals (MPa)
Young's modulus for steel is approximately 200 GPa
Yield strength is the maximum stress in the elastic region
commonMistakes: Confusing stress with force
Ignoring lateral strain (Poisson's ratio)
Applying Hooke's Law beyond the elastic region
Not accounting for temperature effects on material properties

faqs.question: What is Young's modulus?
faqs.answer: Young's modulus (E) measures material stiffness. It represents the ratio of stress to strain in the elastic region. Steel (200 GPa) is stiffer than aluminum (70 GPa).

faqs.question: What is the difference between stress and strain?
faqs.answer: Stress is force distributed over area (tension or compression). Strain is the ratio of deformation to original length. Stress causes strain.

faqs.question: When does a material fail?
faqs.answer: Material fails when stress exceeds yield strength (permanent deformation) or ultimate tensile strength (fracture). Safety factors protect against failure.

hydraulic_cylinder.title: Hydraulic Cylinder Calculator
hydraulic_cylinder.description: Calculate force, pressure, and area for hydraulic cylinders and systems.
hydraulic_cylinder.force_tooltip: Output force of the cylinder in Newtons (N)
hydraulic_cylinder.area_tooltip: Cross-sectional area of the piston in square centimeters
hydraulic_cylinder.piston_diameter_tooltip: Outer diameter of the piston/bore in millimeters
hydraulic_cylinder.rod_diameter_tooltip: Diameter of the piston rod in millimeters (for double-acting cylinders)
hydraulic_cylinder.velocity_tooltip: Speed of piston movement in meters per second

errors.rod_smaller: Rod diameter must be smaller than piston diameter

hydraulic_cylinder.info_description: This calculator determines the force, pressure, and sizing parameters for hydraulic cylinder applications.
hydraulic_cylinder.formula_pressure: Pressure equals Force divided by Area
hydraulic_cylinder.formula_area: Area equals Force divided by Pressure
hydraulic_cylinder.pascals_law_explanation: Pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions. F = P x A is the fundamental equation for hydraulic systems.

howItWorks.title: How the Hydraulic Cylinder Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: F = P × A, P = F / A, A = F / P
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator computes force, pressure, and piston area for hydraulic cylinders using Pascal's Law. Applied pressure transmits equally throughout the confined fluid.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select what to calculate (force, pressure, or area)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter piston diameter (and rod diameter for double-acting cylinders)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter known pressure or force

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review results including extension and retraction forces

seoTips: Extension force is greater than retraction force (due to rod area)
commonMistakes: Ignoring rod area when calculating retraction force
Not accounting for seal friction losses
Exceeding safe operating pressure
Ignoring pressure losses in lines and valves

faqs.question: Why is extension force greater than retraction force?
faqs.answer: During extension, pressure acts on the full piston area. During retraction, the rod area is subtracted from the piston area, reducing effective area and resulting force.

faqs.question: How do I select the right cylinder size?
faqs.answer: Determine required force and available system pressure. Area = Force / Pressure. Then calculate piston diameter from the area. Add 20-30% safety factor.

faqs.question: What is a safe operating pressure?
faqs.answer: Safe pressure is typically 70-80% of test pressure. Standard cylinders operate at 160-250 bar, heavy-duty cylinders reach 400-700 bar.
